body: Argparse is part of the standard library and does not need to be separately installed.  Removed the need to install it separately via pip.  Python standard lib is license compatible with Apache.

Ahh I see I thought there was some weirdness with GPL, but as I look it's
Python licensed now. It only became part of the standard package as of 2.7
and I think ambari requires 2.6...is there any issue installing this on the
vagrant vm?

Sorry I'm on my phone since wifi on my computer is slightly busted and it's
a bit hard to investigate fully or type easily ;)

On Fri, Apr 15, 2016 at 17:48 Nick Allen notifications@github.com wrote:

> Argparse is part of the standard library and does not need to be
> separately installed. Removed the need to install it separately via pip.
> Python standard lib is license compatible with Apache.
> 
> 窶能n> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-metron/pull/76#issuecomment-210542984

Interesting.  I manually deployed on CentOS 6 with the latest change and it worked.  But it appears `argparse` was already installed by something else.  This node went through a partial Metron install, but no pycapa.

```
[vagrant@node1 pycapa]$ ls -l /usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/argparse*
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 87791 Mar 31  2011 /usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/argparse.py
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 66661 Jul 23  2015 /usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/argparse.pyc
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 66491 Jul 23  2015 /usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/argparse.pyo

/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/argparse-1.2.1-py2.6.egg-info:
total 16
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root    1 Jul 23  2015 dependency_links.txt
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 2927 Jul 23  2015 PKG-INFO
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root  250 Jul 23  2015 SOURCES.txt
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root    9 Jul 23  2015 top_level.txt
```

Whether it is standard lib or installed via pip, the license issue is moot now right?  So I could just revert the last commit since I know the original code worked on 2.6 and 2.7?

Yeah the license is fine. We are going to have it installed in the vagrant
box as part of ansible, right?

A nice benefit with this change is that the default deployment produces Snort alerts in the dashboard.  I think I've been asked how to "turn on snort alerts" quite a few times. ;)
I noticed there are a coupe sample config json files (bro.json and global.json) being added to Metron-Common.  There are already sample configs in Metron-Testing.  Are these needed?
+1 this looks really good. Ran through the tests no problem.
@franklu1 put in a lot of work for this PR but his name was in a commit that got squashed.  Whoever merges this please include him so he gets credit.

Yes, the global.json is different, targeted at the exact test I am running. I don't need the bro.json, but unfortunately the config loader dies without a sensors directory and git wants it to be populated. 
I'm going to be putting up a Jira on that behavior shortly, once it's completed, that file can (and the enclosing directory) can go away.
+1 looks good!
The docs on how to turn on Snort alerts are documented in the wiki here: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/METRON/Adding+Dummy+Snort+Data+for+Load+Testing

+1 on this, looks great!

+1 Deployed successfully on EC2. All existing feeds worked out of the box.  Followed manual instructions to deploy topology. Was able to successfully open and validate the pcap file produced by the Metron UI.

tl;dr I'm -1 on a small piece of this changeset, see below for why.

Looking over this PR, it seems to be an aggregation of 4 JIRAs, METRON-122, METRON-91 (expose tags) and 2 new JIRAs, one for Bluecoat and 1 to fix the enrichment topology.

It's a bummer because I'm +1 on everything but how exposing tags/skip_tags was handled. So although everything else looks great, I have to be -1 on the whole changeset.

I'm -1 on that because it operates outside of the Vagrant paradigm and requires the user to enter the Vagrant password. Here's a more vagrantish solution:

Add:

```
require 'getoptlong'

opts = GetoptLong.new(
  [ '--ansible-tags', GetoptLong::OPTIONAL_ARGUMENT ],
  [ '--ansible-skip-tags', GetoptLong::OPTIONAL_ARGUMENT ]
)

ansibleTags=''
ansibleSkipTags=''

opts.each do |opt, arg|
  case opt
    when '--ansible-tags'
      ansibleTags=arg
    when '--ansible-skip-tags'
      ansibleSkipTags=arg
  end
end

puts " Running with ansible-tags: " + ansibleTags.split(",").to_s if ansibleTags != ''
puts " Running with ansible-skip-tags: " + ansibleSkipTags.split(",").to_s if ansibleSkipTags != ''
```

To the top of the Vagrantfile (under the license).

Then make the config loop look like this:

```
  # provisioning
  config.vm.provision :ansible do |ansible|
    ansible.playbook = "../../playbooks/metron_full_install.yml"
    ansible.sudo = true
    ansible.tags = ansibleTags.split(",") if ansibleTags != ''
    ansible.skip_tags = ansibleSkipTags.split(",") if ansibleSkipTags != ''
    ansible.inventory_path = "../../inventory/singlenode-vagrant"
  end
```

That should (we'd have to test it) allow us to remove the new ansible.cfg unless you wanted to keep the custom control_path. You could also get rid of run_ansible_role.sh and run_enrichment_role.sh (it would be `vagrant --ansible-tags=enrichment provsion` )

@dlyle65535 thanks for the suggestions, they make sense and I will add them in.  

However, I think we should keep the scripts and change them to call the vagrant command.  The idea is for someone to be able to rerun a role without having to remember or look up the vagrant syntax.  From my perspective running "run_enrichment_role.sh" is much more intuitive than running "vagrant --ansible-tags=enrichment provision".  The whole purpose of adding these scripts is to make it easy for a developer to test and deploy changes without needing detailed knowledge of how metron-deployment works.

I just thought of another potential issue with this approach.  If we decide to publish a pre-built image of the single node vagrant machine, running this script won't work if the private key file generated by vagrant up is missing.

I'm not sure that `ansible-playbook -i metron-deployment/inventory/singlenode-vagrant/hosts metron-deployment/playbooks/metron_install.yml --tags enrichment -u vagrant -k` is more intuitive than `run_enrichment.sh` for the relatively common task of redeploying.

There is enough differing opinion here, though, that I think perhaps the prudent thing to do is punt any vagrant changes to another PR.  Can we just keep the `run_enrichment.sh` shell script and have it directly call the ansible-playbook command to give a bit of a shortcut for deployment?

EDIT:  Perhaps we can call the script "redeploy.sh" instead of run_enrichment.sh too, since that's what it's doing.

Heh, yeah, we're in full agreement there. That command looks horrible. Glad I didn't suggest it.

I did suggest `vagrant --tags=enrichment provision` which, I think, is at least as intuitive as run_enrichment.sh and perhaps more so if one has a background in Vagrant and/or Ansible.

I also think that `ansible-playbook -i ec2.py playbook.yml --tags=enrichment` is at least as intuitive and perhaps more so if one has a background in Ansible. It's an up arrow-ctrl-e-few keystrokes away. :)

Both of those have the added advantages of supporting other tags as well and in the case of ansible-playbook are fully documented already.

That said- I'm _still_ not against the script, I just don't see it as a viable replacement for exposing tags and skip-tags.

EDIT: actually, I'm now suggesting `vagrant --tags=enrichment -- provision` which seems a little kludgy to me, but at least it's standard Ruby getoptslong, so it's expected. That fixes the -f issue that @merrimanr noticed.

Upon further review- I think I have something working that doesn't need the extra '--'.

What would you guys think of the following?
- Remove the singlenode-vagrant stuff from this PR
- I'll push what I've been able to work up for that under METRON-91 (unless @merrimanr has sorted it, then he can)
- For @merrimanr 's concern about pre-built dev images, let's see what it would take to make something like that vagrant upable (I think it's just adding a push provider to the Vagrantfile and setting up an Atlas account) so whatever we do will work with all singlenode dev-type images

@dlyle65535, I think that's a good plan but I agree with @cestella that we should punt it to a separate Jira.  Sounds like there are some unknowns and things we need to work out to arrive at a solution everyone is comfortable with.  The script included in this pull request works fine and is valuable for testing new parsers in the single node VM.  Any harm in leaving it in until we come up with something better?
With @merrimanr 's latest commit, we can consider the METRON-91 stuff separately, so I'm removing my -1 vote. Thanks!

It would also be good to see a README in there describing its purpose.  It doesn't have to be anything fancy.  I did the same with `metron-deployment/vagrant/fastcapa-vagrant/README.md`

I know these fell out of another PR, but we don't have their use documented anywhere.  Even some commentary at the top of the script itself, would make me a happy camper.

Will add a README and fix the file name.  In regards to the suggestion from @nickwallen to name the image something more appropriate (I agree with him there), does anyone have suggestions for a different name?

Just to help frame the naming conversation, here is how 'single-node-vagrant' differs from the contribution of this PR.
- `vagrant/singlenode-vagrant` builds from scratch a complete developer image. 
- `vagrant/hackathon-image-vagrant` downloads a pre-built image from Atlas saving gobs and gobs of time

Correct me, if this is not the best description.
How does `hackathon-image-vagrant` differ from `devimage-vagrant`?

@nickwallen - that's exactly right from my POV. Here's the use cases I had in mind for each:
- `vagrant/singlenode-vagrant` - useful for testing full deploys
- `vagrant/devimage-vagrant` - preloaded with full HDP, deploys Metron. Useful for devs testing changes to Metron.
- `vagrant/codelab-vagrant` - (this is a name recommendation for the hackathon image) preloaded with light HDP (no SNN, Yarn, MR2) and Storm topologies loaded but disabled. Good for tutorials and GrokParser testing.
And just to be clear, this is just a stop-gap measure until this kind of functionality gets integrated into a proper Metron UI.
It might make sense to rename singlenode and devimage so that they are more similar since they result in the same image just in different ways. Trying to think of good names...

Suggestions...
`singlenode-vagrant` -> `dev-image` or `dev-image-full`
`devimage-vagrant` -> `dev-image-quick`

Do we even need the `*-vagrant` part of the naming convention since all of these exist within the `metron-deployment/vagrant` directory already?
And whatever naming convention we come up with, we will want to change `metron-deployment/vagrant/fastcapa-vagrant` to match.
